courses.name: Introduction to Software Engineering
courses.description: Specification, design, implementation and maintenance of large, multi-module software systems. Principles, techniques, methodologies and tools for computer aided software engineering (CASE); human-computer interfaces, reactive systems, hardware-software interfaces and distributed applications.

courses.name: Computer Hardware and Operating Systems
courses.description: Instruction sets, pipelining, code optimization, caching, virtual memory management, dynamically linked libraries, exception processing, execution time of programs.

courses.name: Intermediate Algorithm Design and Analysis
courses.description: Systematic study of basic concepts and techniques in the design and analysis of algorithms, illustrated from various problem areas. Topics include: models of computation; choice of data structures; graph-theoretic, algebraic, and text processing algorithms.
courses.warnings: Prerequisites also include: 6 credits of 2nd year MATH or STAT; or 3 credits of 2nd year MATH or STAT with a grade of 72% or better.

courses.name: Numerical Computation for Algebraic Problems
courses.description: Numerical techniques for basic mathematical processes involving no discretization, and their analysis. Solution of linear systems, including analysis of round-off errors; norms and condition number; introduction to iterative techniques in linear algebra, including eigenvalue problems; solution to nonlinear equations.
courses.warnings: Prerequisites also include: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223.

courses.name: Numerical Approximation and Discretization
courses.description: Numerical techniques for basic mathematical processes involving discretization, and their analysis. Interpolation and approximation, including splines and least squares data fitting; numerical differentiation and integration; introduction to numerical initial value ordinary differential equations.
courses.warnings: Prerequisites also include: One of MATH 101, MATH 103, MATH 105, MATH 121 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223.

courses.name: Introduction to Relational Databases
courses.description: Overview of database systems, ER models, logical database design and normalization, formal relational query languages, SQL and other commercial languages,data warehouses, special topics.

courses.name: Definition of Programming Languages
courses.description: Comparative study of advanced programming language features. Statement types, data types, variable binding, parameter passing mechanisms. Methods for syntactic and semantic description of programming languages.

courses.name: Functional and Logic Programming
courses.description: Principles of symbolic computing, using languages based upon first-order logic and the lambda calculus. Algorithms for implementing such languages. Applications to artificial intelligence and knowledge representation.

courses.name: Computer Graphics
courses.description: Human vision and colour; geometric transformations; algorithms for 2-D and 3-D graphics; hardware and system architectures; shading and lighting; animation. (Consult the Credit Exclusion list within the Faculty of Science section of the Calendar.)
courses.warnings: Prerequisites also include: One of MATH 200, MATH 253 and one of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223

courses.name: Internet Computing
courses.description: Computer networking, basic communication protocols, network infrastructure and routing. Common application-level protocols and principles associated with developing distributed applications.

courses.name: Software Engineering Project
courses.description: The design, implementation, and test of a large software system, using a team approach.

courses.name: Introduction to Artificial Intelligence
courses.description: Problem-solving and planning; state/action models and graph searching. Natural language understanding Computational vision. Applications of artificial intelligence.

courses.name: Machine Learning and Data Mining
courses.description: Models of algorithms for dimensionality reduction, nonlinear regression, classification, clustering and unsupervised learning; applications to computer graphics, computer games, bio-informatics, information retrieval, e-commerce, databases, computer vision and artificial intelligence.
courses.warnings: Prerequisites also include: One of MATH 152, MATH 221, MATH 223 and one of STAT 200, STAT 203, STAT 241, STAT 251, MATH 302, STAT 302, MATH 318, BIOL 300

courses.name: Introduction to Human Computer Interaction Methods
courses.description: Basic tools and techniques, teaching a systematic approach to interface design, task analysis, analytic and empirical evaluation methods.

courses.name: Computation, Programs, and Programming
courses.description: Fundamental program and computation structures. Introductory programming skills. Computation as a tool for information processing, simulation and modeling, and interacting with the world.

courses.name: Models of Computation
courses.description: Physical and mathematical structures of computation. Boolean algebra and combinations logic circuits; proof techniques; functions and sequential circuits; sets and relations; finite state machines; sequential instruction execution.

courses.name: Software Construction
courses.description: Design, development, and analysis of robust software components. Topics such as software design, computational models, data structures, debugging, and testing.

courses.name: Introduction to Computer Systems
courses.description: Software architecture, operating systems, and I/O architectures. Relationships between application software, operating systems, and computing hardware; critical sections, deadlock avoidance, and performance; principles and operation of disks and networks.

courses.name: Basic Algorithms and Data Structures
courses.description: Design and analysis of basic algorithms and data structures; algorithm analysis methods, searching and sorting algorithms, basic data structures, graphs and concurrency.

courses.name: Advanced Relational Databases
courses.description: Physical database design, indexing, relational query processing and optimization, transaction processing, concurrency control, crash recovery, data warehouses, data cubes, views, special topics.

courses.name: Computational Optimization
courses.description: Formulation and analysis of algorithms for continuous and discrete optimization problems; linear, nonlinear, network, dynamic, and integer optimization; large-scale problems; software packages and their implementation; duality theory and sensitivity.

courses.name: Advanced Software Engineering
courses.description: Specification, design, construction and validation of multi-version software systems.

courses.name: Introduction to Compiler Construction
courses.description: A practical introduction to lexical analysis, syntactic analysis, type-checking, code generation and optimization. This will be used to design and implement a compiler for a small language.

courses.name: Advanced Operating Systems
courses.description: Process synchronization and communication schemes, including message-passing and concepts of monitor and serializer. Virtual memory systems management and the problem of information sharing in such systems. The working set principle. Traps and interrupt handling. Elementary queuing theory and its application such as process scheduling, system balancing and load control. File systems and operating system design methodologies.

courses.name: Distributed Systems
courses.description: Concepts and design of distributed systems. Communication architecture and models for interprocess communication. Process migration, naming, distributed file systems, fault tolerance, and concurrency control.

courses.name: Parallel Computation
courses.description: Algorithms, architectures, and programming paradigms for parallel computation. Shared memory, message passing, and data parallel architectures and programming models. Parallel algorithms including reduce, scan, and sorting networks. Reasoning about the correctness of parallel programs. Performance analysis and measurement for parallel programs.

courses.name: Advanced Algorithms Design and Analysis
courses.description: The study of advanced topics in the design and analysis of algorithms and associated data structures. Topics include algorithms for graph-theoretic; algebraic and geometric problems; algorithms on nonsequential models; complexity issues; approximation algorithms.

courses.name: Introduction to Theory of Computing
courses.description: Characterizations of computability (using machines, languages and functions). Universality, equivalence and Church's thesis. Unsolvable problems. Restricted models of computation. Finite automata, grammars and formal languages.

courses.name: Intelligent Systems
courses.description: Principles and techniques underlying the design, implementation and evaluation of intelligent computational systems. Applications of artificial intelligence to natural language understanding, image understanding and computer-based expert and advisor systems. Advanced symbolic programming methodology.

courses.name: Computer Vision
courses.description: Introduction to the processing and interpretation of images. Image sensing, sampling, and filtering. Algorithms for colour analysis, texture description, stereo imaging, motion interpretation, 3D shape recovery, and recognition.
courses.warnings: Prerequisites also include: MATH 200 and MATH 221

courses.name: Computer Animation
courses.description: Motion in computer graphics for characters and their environments. Keyframing, inverse kinematics, particle systems, rigid body dynamics, contact and collision, controller-based active motion, motion capture.

courses.name: Computers and Society
courses.description: Impact of computer technology on society; historical perspectives; social and economic consequences of large-scale information processing systems and automatic control; legal and ethical problems in computer applications. Computers and the individual: machine versus human capabilities, fact and fancy; problematic interface between man and machine.
courses.warnings: Requires at least 3rd year standing and 3 credits of Computer Science

courses.name: Advanced Methods for Human Computer Interaction
courses.description: Design and evaluation methodologies and theories; formal models of the user including visual, motor, and information processing; advanced evaluation methods including laboratory experiments and field studies; HCI research frontiers.
courses.warnings: Prerequisites also include: one of STAT 200, STAT 241.

courses.name: Algorithms in Bioinformatics
courses.description: Sequence alignment, phylogenetic tree reconstruction, prediction of RNA and protein structure, gene finding and sequence annotation, gene expression, and biomolecular computing.
courses.warnings: Prerequisites also include: 6 credits of BIOL beyond BIOL 111
